Quinoa Salad with Avocado and Chickpeas

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to a refreshing culinary experience with our Quinoa Salad with Avocado and Chickpeas! This vibrant and nutritious dish is not only packed with flavor but is also a powerhouse of health benefits. Quinoa, the star ingredient, is a complete protein that provides energy and keeps you feeling full, making it an ideal choice for those looking to maintain a balanced diet. Paired with creamy avocado, hearty chickpeas, and a medley of fresh vegetables like cherry tomatoes and cucumbers, this salad is a feast for both the eyes and the palate. Plus, it’s incredibly easy to whip up, making it perfect for meal prep, a light lunch, or a delightful side dish for gatherings. With a zesty lime dressing that ties all the ingredients together, this Quinoa Salad is not only delicious but also a visually appealing dish that will impress your family and friends. Whether you’re a seasoned chef or a beginner in the kitchen, this recipe is a must-try for anyone seeking a healthy and satisfying meal option. Let’s dive into the recipe and discover how simple it is to make this wholesome salad!

Ingredients

quinoa

Always rinse quinoa before cooking to remove its natural coating, called saponin, which can impart a bitter taste. If you don't have quinoa, you can substitute it with couscous, bulgur, or even brown rice, but adjust cooking times accordingly.

chickpeas (canned, drained and rinsed)

Canned chickpeas are convenient, but you can also use dried chickpeas that you soak and cook yourself for a firmer texture. To enhance flavor, consider roasting them with spices like paprika or cumin before adding them to the salad.

avocado

Choose ripe avocados that yield slightly to gentle pressure. You can substitute with diced mango or even cooked and cooled sweet potatoes for a different texture and flavor. To prevent browning, add lime juice immediately after cutting.

cherry tomatoes

Use ripe cherry tomatoes for the best flavor; look for ones that are vibrant and slightly soft. If unavailable, you can substitute with grape tomatoes or regular tomatoes diced into small pieces. Roasting them slightly before adding can enhance their sweetness.

cucumber

For a crunchier texture, use English cucumbers as they have fewer seeds. You can also substitute with diced bell peppers or zucchini for a different flavor profile. To enhance flavor, sprinkle with a bit of salt and let sit for a few minutes before adding to the salad.

red onion

Soak chopped red onion in cold water for 10 minutes to soften its sharpness if you prefer a milder flavor. You can substitute with green onions or shallots for a different taste. If you want a sweeter flavor, try caramelizing them briefly before adding.

fresh cilantro

Cilantro adds a fresh and bright flavor, but if you're not a fan, you can substitute with parsley or basil. For an extra kick, add a pinch of chopped jalapeño or a sprinkle of cumin.

lime juice

Freshly squeezed lime juice is best for maximum flavor; bottled lime juice can be used in a pinch but may lack freshness. You can substitute lime with lemon juice for a slightly different taste.

olive oil

Use high-quality extra virgin olive oil for the best flavor. If you’re looking for a different oil, avocado oil or walnut oil can be great alternatives. A dash of sesame oil can also add an interesting flavor dimension.

salt

Adjust salt to taste; consider using sea salt or Himalayan pink salt for a gourmet touch. For a lower-sodium version, use a salt substitute or herbs to enhance flavor.

pepper

Freshly ground black pepper will provide better flavor than pre-ground. For an extra kick, try incorporating crushed red pepper flakes or a dash of cayenne.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Rinse the Quinoa

    Start by rinsing 1 cup of quinoa under cold water in a fine-mesh strainer. This step is crucial as it helps to remove the natural coating called saponin, which can give the quinoa a bitter taste. Make sure to rinse it thoroughly until the water runs clear.

  • Step 2: Cook the Quinoa

    In a medium saucepan, combine the rinsed quinoa with 2 cups of water. Bring the mixture to a boil over medium-high heat. Once boiling, reduce the heat to low, cover the saucepan, and let it simmer for about 15 minutes. After this time, the water should be fully absorbed. Fluff the quinoa with a fork and let it cool for a few minutes.

  • Step 3: Prepare the Salad Ingredients

    While the quinoa is cooling, prepare the other salad ingredients. Dice 1 avocado, halve 1 cup of cherry tomatoes, and dice 1 cucumber. Finely chop 1/4 of a red onion and 1/4 cup of fresh cilantro. Having all your ingredients ready will make the assembly process easier and quicker.

  • Step 4: Combine Salad Ingredients

    In a large mixing bowl, combine the cooled quinoa, drained and rinsed chickpeas (1 can, 15 oz), diced avocado, cherry tomatoes, cucumber, red onion, and chopped cilantro. Mix gently to avoid mashing the avocado.

  • Step 5: Prepare the Dressing

    In a small bowl, whisk together the lime juice (2 tablespoons), olive oil (2 tablespoons), and add salt and pepper to taste. This dressing will enhance the flavors of the salad and add a refreshing tang.

  • Step 6: Dress the Salad

    Pour the dressing over the quinoa salad mixture. Gently toss everything together until all ingredients are evenly coated with the dressing. Be careful not to break the avocado too much.

  • Step 7: Serve or Chill

    You can serve the salad immediately for a fresh, vibrant dish, or refrigerate it for up to an hour to enhance the flavors and enjoy a chilled salad. This makes it a perfect option for meal prep or gatherings.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I rinse quinoa, and why is it important?

To rinse quinoa, place it in a fine-mesh strainer and run it under cold water for a few seconds, stirring gently. This removes the natural coating called saponin, which can taste bitter. Rinsing ensures your quinoa has a pleasant, nutty flavor.

How do I know when quinoa is cooked?

Quinoa is done when it has absorbed all the water and the grains have a little 'tail' (the germ) that separates from the seed. This usually takes about 15 minutes of simmering on low heat. If there’s still water left, cover and cook for a few more minutes.

What can I substitute for chickpeas in this salad?

If you don’t have chickpeas, you can use black beans, kidney beans, or even cooked lentils. These alternatives provide similar protein and texture to the salad.

How can I prevent my avocado from browning?

To prevent browning, you can sprinkle some lime juice over the diced avocado right after cutting it. The acidity helps slow down the oxidation process.

Is it safe to eat raw red onion?

Yes, raw red onion is safe to eat! It has a milder flavor compared to yellow or white onions. If you find it too strong, you can soak the chopped red onion in cold water for about 10 minutes to mellow the flavor.

What if I don’t have fresh cilantro?

If you don’t have fresh cilantro, you can substitute it with parsley for a different flavor. You can also skip it if you're not a fan of cilantro!

How long can I store the quinoa salad?

You can store the quinoa salad in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. It’s best enjoyed fresh, but the flavors will continue to meld in the fridge.

Can I add more vegetables to this salad?

Absolutely! Feel free to add any vegetables you like, such as bell peppers, corn, or grated carrots. Just make sure to cut them into similar sizes to keep the texture consistent.

What can I serve with quinoa salad?

Quinoa salad can be a complete meal on its own, but it pairs well with grilled chicken, fish, or a side of roasted vegetables. It’s versatile!

How do I safely cut an avocado?

To safely cut an avocado, slice it in half lengthwise and twist to separate the halves. Use a spoon to carefully scoop out the flesh. If needed, use a knife to carefully remove the pit, but be cautious!

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This dish is naturally gluten-free and vegan, making it suitable for a variety of dietary preferences. For those watching their sodium intake, opt for low-sodium canned chickpeas or cook dried chickpeas from scratch. To enhance protein content further, consider adding nuts such as walnuts or almonds, or seeds like pumpkin or sunflower seeds. For a grain-free option, substitute quinoa with riced cauliflower.

Pairings

This Quinoa Salad with Avocado and Chickpeas pairs wonderfully with grilled chicken or shrimp for added protein, making it an excellent light lunch or dinner option. For a vegetarian pairing, consider serving it with roasted vegetables or falafel. As for beverages, a crisp white wine such as Sauvignon Blanc or a refreshing iced tea with mint complements the fresh flavors beautifully. Sparkling water with a squeeze of lime can also enhance the meal experience.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the salad in a large, colorful bowl to showcase its vibrant ingredients. For an elegant touch, garnish with additional chopped cilantro and lime wedges. If serving as a main dish, consider adding a sprinkle of feta cheese or crumbled goat cheese for a creamy contrast. For a buffet or potluck, provide individual portions in mason jars for easy transport and a fun presentation. This salad can be served chilled or at room temperature, making it versatile for any occasion.

#

Quinoa Salad with Avocado and Chickpeas

30 min
$10
300 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 4

Dietary Tags:

VegetarianGluten-FreeHigh-Protein

Cuisine:

AmericanMediterranean

Course:

Main CourseSide Dish

Tags:

SaladHealthyEasy

Description

A refreshing and nutritious salad packed with protein, healthy fats, and vibrant flavors.

Ingredients

  • quinoa: 1 cup
  • chickpeas (canned, drained and rinsed): 1 can (15 oz)
  • avocado: 1, diced
  • cherry tomatoes: 1 cup, halved
  • cucumber: 1, diced
  • red onion: 1/4, finely chopped
  • fresh cilantro: 1/4 cup, chopped
  • lime juice: 2 tablespoons
  • olive oil: 2 tablespoons
  • salt: to taste
  • pepper: to taste
